Hydroxymethylfurfural oxidation over unsupported Pd-Au alloy catalysts prepared by pulsed laser ablation: Synergistic and compositional effects Konstantin L. Bimetallic nanoparticles are of high interest for electronics, photonics, biomedicine, and heterogeneous catalysis. To reveal the effects of structure and composition of bimetallic nanoparticles on catalytic properties, unsupported particles with clean surfaces and well-defined characteristics should be considered. Herein, colloidal Au, Pd, and Au-Pd catalysts prepared by pulsed laser ablation in liquid are studied in 5-hydroxymethylfurfural (HMF) oxidation. The catalysts are characterized by ELS, UV–vis spectroscopy, XRD, TEM, and SAED methods. The results show the formation of Au1−yPdy alloy particles that remain stable in pure water without the presence of any surfactant and feature higher performance towards formylfuran carboxylic and furandicarboxylic acids as compared with monometallic samples. The results indicate the combined benefits of Pd1−yAuy alloys in aerobic catalytic HMF oxidation due to a synergistic effect comprising the formation of Au-Pd interface in alloy nanoparticles, where the metals activate different moieties of HMF molecule. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords Pd-Au Alloys Bimetallic catalyst HMF oxidation Synergistic effect PLAL Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction A transition to an efficient and environmentally sustainable system using renewable sources is a trend of the near future [1]. Therefore, relevant research on the renewable biomass conversion into valuable products has attracted much attention of scientific, industrial and governmental communities [2]. Among the various products obtained from lignocellulosic biomass, 5-hydroxymethylfurfural (HMF) is considered one of the most promising raw materials and the most important multifunctional platform molecules that can be further converted into a wide range of valuable materials ranging from healthcare products to polymers [3–9]. Among others, formylfuran carboxylic (FFCA) and furandicarboxylic (FDCA) acids are important products serving as an alternative source for pharmaceutics and polymer production [3,6]. Diverse catalytic materials were proposed for the HMF selective oxidation that influenced the selectivity towards desired products [7,10–15], with supported noble metals (Au, Pd, Pt, Ag, etc.) being the most abundant and well-proven catalytic systems. The support, active phase, and reaction conditions affect the catalytic performance. Among the noble metal-based catalysts, the Au-based composites show better selectivity and stability for the HMF aerobic oxidation into FDCA in water [7,11]. Nevertheless, deactivation of the metal-based catalysts with process intermediates and by-products is observed. To further improve the Au-based catalysts, an approach based on bimetallic compositions, specifically alloying with Pd [16,17] (including Au-Pd species supported on carbon-based supports [18,19], NiO [20] or hydrotalcite [21,22]), Ag [23], Cu [24] or Pt [25], can be effective due to the synergistic effect of catalyst components [27–30]. This effect is expressed in the increase of activity, selectivity, stability and other catalyst characteristics, while its nature is poorly understood [26]. Specifically, the activity and stability of the Au/C catalyst in the HMF oxidation to FDCA was improved by adding Pd [27]. The Au-Cu/TiO2 catalyst with Au:Cu = 1:3 (wt%) showed the highest FDCA yield (>30%, while the FDCA yields for single-metal catalysts were ∼10–15%) among studied gold-copper samples under reaction conditions used (60ºC, 10 bar O2, HMF:NaOH = 1:4) [28]. Bimetallic Pd–Au/C anode catalysts with 2:1 and 1:2 molar ratios showed much higher FDCA molar yields (64% for PdAu (2:1)/C, 83% for PdAu (1:2)/C) at 25 °C and anode potential of 0.6 V vs. RHE) as compared with the monometallic Pd/C and Au/C samples (28% and 1%, respectively) [29]. The AuPd NPs embedded in a titanosilicate matrix showed good efficiency in the base-free HMF oxidation (100ºC, 1 bar O2) [30], with Au4Pd1@SiTi catalyst showing the highest activity (35%) and selectivity to FDCA (22%) among the monometallic and bimetallic samples studied. It is noteworthy that although supported bimetallic catalyst formulations showed promising catalytic results, still it is rather complicated (or even impossible) to understand the individual performance of bimetallic species on the support surfaces and the effects caused by their composition in such systems. Thus, to reveal the effect of the structure and composition of bimetallic particles on the catalytic properties, the unsupported NPs with well-defined characteristics should be prepared and studied. Pulsed laser ablation in liquids (PLAL) attracts attention as an alternative approach to obtain high-purity colloidal particles without any surfactant or organic ligand in contrast to chemical methods [21,31] that feature a number of inherent disadvantages, particularly the presence of various substances in the resulting colloids that can strongly affect the characteristics of colloidal particles, e.g., by blocking/capping active sites [32]. Using metallic target and varying the ablation conditions, the PLAL enables highly reproducible synthesis of colloids of various compositions such as metals, alloys, oxides and semiconductors [33–35]. In case of alloys, while the homogeneous alloy targets are not always available, which largely limits the production of PLAL alloyed NPs [35], several approaches were proposed. For instance, the unsupported AuPd NPs can be generated by laser fragmentation irradiating Au target in a Na2PdCl4 solution with nanosecond and femtosecond lasers [36], with the latter laser producing the NPs with a relatively uniform size. The presence of Pd ions also allowed improving the size distribution when nanosecond laser was employed. The Au/Pd(II) core-shell colloidal NPs were synthesized by PLA in solution of Au target in PdCl2 solution [37], and the shell thickness was a function of the PdCl2 concentration. Although high performance of supported bimetallic AuPd NPs was demonstrated, to the best of our knowledge, there were no attempts to test the individual performance of unsupported AuPd species in HMF oxidation. Thus, the present work is focused on the preparation of colloidal bimetallic Au-Pd NPs by PLA of mixtures of Pd and Au dispersions in water and study their structural, optical, electrokinetic properties as well as catalytic performance in the HMF oxidation. 2 Materials and methods 2.1 Synthesis of monometallic Au and Pd and bimetallic Au-Pd NPs by PLAL The Pd and Au dispersions were prepared by the PLA of Pd and Au targets, respectively, in distilled water using Nd:YAG laser (1064 nm, 20 Hz, 7 ns). The detailed description of the PLA unit and procedure is presented in Ref. [34]. The plates of high-purity (99.98%) metallic gold and palladium were used as targets. The target was weighed before and after the ablation process to determine the concentration of the dispersion obtained. To prepare bimetallic Au-Pd NPs, an approach based on a laser fusion of individual Au and Pt NPs in colloid was used. The xAu100-xPd dispersions (where x and 100-x are wt% of the metal) were obtained by laser irradiation of mixtures of Pd and Au dispersions. The procedure to prepare the bimetallic Au-Pd NPs was similar to that for the preparation of bismuth silicates presented in Ref. [38]. Concentrations of Au, Pd and xAu1-xPd dispersions obtained were within 110 and 135 mg/l (Table S1). 2.2 Sample characterization The catalysts prepared were characterized by UV–vis spectroscopy, X-ray diffraction (XRD), electrophoretic light scattering (ELS), transmission electron microscopy (TEM), and selected area electron diffraction (SAED) methods. The UV–vis absorption spectra were collected with the Cary100 spectrophotometer (Varian, Australia). Absorption was studied in the 190–900 nm range with 1 nm increments using a quartz cuvette with 2 mm optical path lengths. The XRD patterns were obtained using the XRD-7000 diffractometer (Shimadzu, Japan) with a monochromatic CuKα radiation (1.54 Å) in the 2θ range of 35–50° at a scanning rate of 2°/min. Before the XRD study, the colloidal sample was dried on a watch glass, and the powder obtained was mixed with 80–100 mg of ground amorphous silica to increase the sample volume to fill the cuvette. Data were collected using the Bragg–Brentano geometry. Well-crystallized Si (a=5.4309 Å, λ = 1.540562 Å) was used as an external standard material to calibrate the diffractometer. The full-profile analysis program POWDER CELL 2.4 was used to refine the lattice parameters. The phase composition of the samples was analyzed using the PDF-4 database (Release 2021 RDB), the Vegard law (Fig. S1). The X-ray crystal size (DXRD) was determined using the Scherrer equation. The electrokinetic properties of the dispersions were studied by the ELS using the phase analysis light scattering (PALS) technique on the Omni S/N analyzer equipped with the BI-ZTU autotitrator (Brookhaven, USA). To determine the pH of the isoelectric point (IEP), the dispersion was titrated using diluted (0.001 and 0.1 mol/l) solutions of HNO3. The TEM and SAED data were obtained using the CM 12 electron microscope (Philips, Netherlands) at an accelerating voltage of 120 kV. The camera length was calibrated using the gold standard material. The dispersions were centrifuged followed by the centrifugate excess separation. The concentrated samples were ultrasonically redispersed and then deposited onto Cu grids with amorphous carbon coating and then dried. Particle size distributions were analyzed using the “ParticlesNN” service [39]. 2.3 Catalytic experiments Catalytic tests were carried out in the Parr 5500 HR series compact reactor. Typically, 132 mg HMF, 353 mg NaHCO3, 10.1–11.1 ml catalyst dispersion (110–135 mg/l), and 9.9–10.9 ml distilled water were loaded into the reactor. The final reaction mixture with a total volume of 21 ml was characterized by the following concentrations: 0.05 mol/l HMF, 0.1 mol/l NaHCO3, and 5 × 10−4 mol/l catalyst. Then the reactor was sealed, heated to up to 80 °C and pressurized with O2 to 5 bar. The experiment was carried out at 80 °C with a vigorous stirring at 700 rpm to avoid the mass transfer effect. The composition of the reaction mixture before and after 2, 4, and 22 h reaction was analyzed by a high-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC) using the Prominence-i LC-2030 C chromatograph (Shimadzu, Japan). The Rezex ROA-Organic Acid H+ (8%) LC column and 0.025 M H2SO4 eluent as well as PDA detector were used for separation and registration of the components. The HMF, 5-hydroxymethyl-2-furancarboxylic acid (HMFCA), FDCA, 2,5-diformylfuran (DFF), and FFCA reference solutions were used to calibrate the detector, with compound concentrations being determined from the peak areas. The analysis was carried out at the eluent flow rate of 0.8 ml/min, and an injection volume was 10 μl. Prior to the analysis, 50 μl aliquot taken was diluted with 1 ml of 0.0125 M H2SO4. The HMF conversion, X(HMF), product yield, Y(i), and selectivity, S(i), as well as carbon balance, B, were calculated based on the concentrations determined by HPLC: X HMF = C HMF o − C ( HMF ) C HMF o ∙ 100 % , S i = C ( i ) C HMF o − C ( HMF ) ∙ 100 % , Y i = C ( i ) C HMF o ∙ 100 % , B = C ( HMF ) + ∑ i C ( i ) C HMF o ∙ 100 % , where C(HMF)o and C(HMF) are initial and current HMF concentrations, mol/l; C(i) is current concentration of the i th product, mol/l; i = HFCA, FDCA, DFF, and FFCA. In all experiments, carbon balance was higher than 95% that is in agreement with the HPLC analytical error. 2.4 Computational details The Gaussian’09 program package (Revision C.01) installed at SKIF “Cyberia” supercomputer of Tomsk State University [40] was used for DFT calculations. B3LYP functional [41,42] was used in the calculations. LANL2DZ [43] and 6–31 G [44] basis sets were used for heavy atoms (Au and Pd) and light atoms (C, H, O), respectively. First, the structures of HMF as well as Au20, Pd20, Au10Pd10, and Au8Pd12 clusters were optimized. Then HMF substrate was placed onto each cluster as shown in Fig. S2, and reoptimization of the complex was carried out. To select the optimal cluster structure for the PCM calculations, the complexes were optimized in gas phase. The calculations with the PCM model [45] were carried out using Au8Pd12 cluster. A convergence criterion comprised the energy change below − 1.0D-08 (a.u.). The stationary character of the optimized structures was confirmed by vibrational frequency calculations. The substrate binding energies (BEs) were calculated as a difference between the total energies of the HMF-cluster complex, HMF, and the cluster. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Optical properties, structure, and morphology of metal NPs The optical properties of the metal NPs obtained by PLA in water were studied by UV–vis spectroscopy. Fig. 1 shows typical absorption spectra for Au and Pd dispersions, their mixture (exemplified by the sample with 80 wt% Au and 20 wt% Pd), and bimetallic xAu1-xPd dispersions (exemplified by 80Au20Pd and 60Au40Pd samples) after laser treatment. Besides, typical photographs of Au and Pd dispersions, their mixture (exemplified by 60 wt% Au and 40 wt% Pd sample), and bimetallic xAu1-xPd dispersion (exemplified by 60Au40Pd sample) after laser treatment are shown for visual clarity. The Au dispersion was characterized by the purple-red color typical for gold colloids and high stability. No precipitate was formed for a month. The black Pd dispersion was less stable, with practically complete sedimentation being observed for 2 weeks. However, the precipitate was easily redispersed with ultrasonic treatment. The spectrum for Au dispersion contained the absorption peak for Au NPs surface plasmon resonance (SPR Au) at 523 nm typical for 10–20 nm spherical NPs, while the one for Pd dispersion did not contain any characteristic absorption peaks in the studied spectral range [46,47]. The dark plum-colored mixture of Au and Pd dispersions was settling for 2 h to form stable Au dispersion and Pd precipitate. The spectrum for the mixture of Au and Pd dispersions also contained the SPR Au peak at 523 nm, with its intensity proportionally decreasing due to the dilution of the mixed dispersions relative to the component concentration. The subsequent laser treatment of the mixed dispersions resulted in the formation of black xAu1-xPd dispersions, with no settling being observed. This was accompanied by disappearing of the SPR Au in the absorption spectra for all xAu1-xPd dispersions (the spectra for 40Au60Pd and 20Au80Pd samples were similar to those of 80Au20Pd and 60Au40Pd samples and are not presented) indicating the formation of bimetallic AuyPd1−y alloy particles [48]. Fig. 2 shows the TEM images and particle size distributions for NPs formed as a result of the PLA in water and subsequent fusion in mixed dispersion (exemplified by 60Au40Pd sample, other xAu1-xPd samples feature similar characteristics, Fig. S3). All particles formed are characterized by a spherical shape, which is typical for noble metal particles obtained by the PLAL [33,49,50]. For all Pd-containing samples (Fig. S3), the fractions with particle sizes from 6 to 10 nm (24–48%) and from 10 to 20 nm (∼20%) greatly contribute. For the Au sample, the fraction of particles with sizes of < 10 nm is insignificant (<5%); the particle size for the Au sample is in the range from 10 to 30 nm (∼50%) that is consistent with the absorption spectroscopy data, with the fraction from 30 to 40 nm also making a notable contribution (∼18%). Such differences observed for Pd and xAu1-xPd samples in contrast to Au specimen are caused by different contribution of laser-induced melting and fragmentation processes [33,49]. For the Pd (melting point is 1555 °C) and xAu100-xPd samples (melting points of alloys formed are >1250 °C), defragmentation processes significantly contribute to the size of particles formed, while for Au (melting point is 1064 °C), the sintering notably affects the resulting particle sizes. The shift of the predominant particle size to 10–40 nm observed for Au NPs in comparison with the predominant size of Pd-containing NPs of 6–20 nm does not significantly affect the specific surface area of the samples and the surface area of the sample in the catalytic experiment (Table S1). Fig. 3 shows the SAED patterns for Pd, Au, and 60Au40Pd samples as well as the diffraction profiles generated. The SAED patterns indicate the polycrystallinity of the samples. The analysis of electron diffraction patterns for Pd, Au, and 60Au40Pd samples reveals that a lattice parameter, a, for AuyPd1−y alloy particles is 4.00 Å that is between those of Au (4.07 Å) and Pd (3.95 Å) and corresponds to the particle composition of Au0.4Pd0.6, which is similar to the nominal molar composition of the sample (45 mol.% Au and 55 mol.% Pd). To additionally confirm the formation of AuyPd1−y alloy NPs in the xAu1-xPd dispersions, colloidal samples were dried on a watch glass, and the powders obtained were studied by XRD. Fig. 4 shows the XRD patterns for monometallic Au and Pd samples, their mixture (exemplified by the 80Au20Pd sample), and bimetallic xAu100-xPd samples. According to the XRD data, the monometallic samples are characterized by the cubic Au (ICDD PDF-4 card #04–0784) with the lattice parameter a = 4.080 Å and the mean crystallite size of 61 nm and Pd (ICDD PDF-4 card #46–1043) phase with the lattice parameter a = 3.891 Å and the mean crystallite size of 54 nm. The XRD pattern for their mixture contains reflections of individual metal phases that disappear in the patterns for all bimetallic xAu100-xPd samples after laser treatment of the mixed dispersions. Instead of reflections typical for Au and Pd phases, those placed between them are identified in the partners for the xAu100-xPd samples clearly indicating the formation of the AuyPd1−y alloys. Table 1 shows the determined lattice parameter and the composition of the formed AuyPd1−y alloy determined using the Vegard law. Specifically, the primarily formation of the Au0.65Pd0.35 alloy with the sample composition similar to the one and the admixture of Au-rich Au0.91Pd0.09 alloy was observed for the 80Au20Pd sample. For other bimetallic samples, only one alloy was formed with the composition corresponding to the one in the sample. The presence of the admixture of Au0.91Pd0.09 alloy in the 80Au20Pd sample was associated with the features of crystallization of particles during the plasma cooling due to the mismatch of the solidus and liquidus for such composition. The mean crystallite size of alloys formed does not deviate much from the crystallite size of Au and Pd and varies within 58–61 nm, with the specific surface areas of the samples estimated from the XRD data (Table S2) being similar to those estimated from the TEM data (Table S1). Thereby, the obtained results show that AuyPd1−y alloyed NPs can be synthesized by PLA of individual Pd and Au targets in distilled water followed by laser fusion of Au and Pt NPs in mixed colloid. 3.2 Electrokinetic properties of catalyst dispersions Fig. 5 shows the zeta potential dependences of the metal NPs obtained by PLA in water on the pH of the dispersions. All dispersions are characterized by a negative zeta potential of particles, which is consistent with the literature data [33,51–53]. The zeta potential of particles increases as the pH decreases during titration with the HNO3 solution. However, the dependencies obtained are noticeably distinguished. Specifically, the Pd dispersion is characterized by the zeta potential of − 22.4 ± 0.7 mV at the initial pH of 7.0 and IEP at pH = 3.2, and the Au dispersion is characterized by the zeta potential of − 33 ± 0.4 mV at the initial pH of 5.5 and IEP at pH = 2.3 (Table S3). Despite the additive nature of the zeta potential, the electrokinetic characteristics of bimetallic dispersions are not a superposition of the characteristics of individual particles. Thus, the zeta potential–pH curve for the 80Au20Pd dispersion with low Pd content (∼32 mol.%) is similar to that of the Au sample. However, the type of zeta potential dependences for the 60Au40Pd, 40Au60Pd, and 20Au80Pd dispersions is similar to that observed for Pd sample, but the dependencies are characterized by lower potential values and, thus, are significantly shifted towards lower pH values. The zeta potential–pH curves for the 40Au60Pd and 20Au80Pd dispersions correlate with the one for Au sample at pH < 4. The curve for the 60Au40Pd dispersion is significantly shifted towards the lower pH values, with the IEP being found at pH< 2 (beyond the range of pH determination). The negative zeta potential of NPs is caused by their unique surface chemistry features. Thus, ∼3–6% of the surface atoms of the PLAL-obtained Au NPs are oxidized to Au+ and Au3+ contributing to the high colloidal stability since they can dissociate in water to form Au−O− and Au−CO3 − generating a negatively charged surface layer [52,53]. Similar mechanism was also revealed for the Ag and Pt NPs obtained by PLAL [33,51] and can be transmitted to Pd and bimetallic AuyPd1−y alloys. The lower potential values observed for AuyPd1−y alloy NPs can be assigned to electron charge transfer from Pd to Au [54,55] resulting in the changes of the surface properties for bimetallic xAu1-xPd samples as opposed to the monometallic ones (in particular, in an increase in the strength of the Au−OH and Au−CO3H acid sites formed). Therefore, unlike chemically synthesized NPs, the colloidal Au, Pd, and AuyPd1−y NPs obtained by PLAL are produced and remain stable in pure water without the presence of any additional surfactant or organic ligand molecules. Besides, the changes in the electrokinetic characteristics observed for AuyPd1−y alloy NPs indicate both a dilution of one metal by another (ensemble effect) and a change in the electronic structure of the alloy (electronic effect), but not segregation of one of the metals on the particle surface. 3.3 Catalytic performance Fig. 6 shows the evolution of the reaction mixture composition with the reaction time (specifically in 2, 4, and 22 h) during the HMF oxidation for different catalysts. Table S4 presents the HMF conversion and product yields. The monometallic Pd sample showed the lowest catalytic performance in the HMF oxidation among the sample studied. The HMF conversion was 51% and FDCA yield was less than 6 mol.% in 22 h of the reaction, with the HMFCA being the main product (yield was 29.1 mol.%); the FFCA yield was 15.6 mol.%, while the presence of diformylfuran (DFF) in the products for all catalysts studied was negligible. The monometallic Au sample was characterized by higher catalytic activity in the HMF oxidation, with the HMF conversion reaching 88% in 22 h. However, the main product of the HMF oxidation also was HMFCA (yield was 56.3 mol.%), while FDCA yield was only 7 mol.% in 22 h. These results indicates that the HMF conversion over Au and Pd proceeded mainly through oxidation of the carbonyl group to form HMFCA ( Scheme 1), while the hydroxyl group oxidation to form DFF and FFCA seems to be hindered. The 20Au80Pd sample showed activity and product selectivity similar to those achieved over Pd one, while the bimetallic xAu1-xPd samples with x = 20, 40, and 60 wt% showed a superior catalytic performance in the HMF oxidation. The activity curve for the xAu1-xPd samples features the maximal value for the 60Au40Pd sample with Au0.4Pd0.6 alloy NPs (Pd/Au molar ratio was 3/2) ( Fig. 7). The HMF conversion for this sample reached 82% already in 4 h of the reaction. In 22 h of the reaction, it showed the complete HMF conversion and FDCA yield of 40 mol.%. For the 40Au60Pd, 60Au40Pd and 80Au20Pd samples, the main products of the HMF oxidation were FFCA and FDCA. This indicated that the bimetallic samples favor the subsequent HMF oxidation to FFCA and FDCA (Scheme 1) in contrast to the monometallic Au and Pd. Therefore, the results of the present study on the Au, Pd and Pd-Au NPs clearly show the combined benefits of the Pd1−yAuy alloys in aerobic catalytic HMF oxidation to FDCA, with their composition strongly affecting the catalytic properties. Such an improvement in the catalytic performance of the Pd1−yAuy alloys can be attributed to both ensemble and electronic effects providing the effective oxidation of both carbonyl and hydroxyl groups. A similar effect was previously observed for electrocatalytic HMF oxidation over bimetallic Pd2Au1/C and Pd1Au2/C anode catalysts [29]. The Au/C was found to be highly active for HMF oxidation to HMFCA at all potentials but ceded in activity for subsequent hydroxyl group oxidation at potentials below 1.2 V. The HMF oxidation on Pd/C followed two competitive routes to FDCA, but the oxidation of carbonyl groups occurred much slower. Bimetallic catalysts Pd2Au1/C and Pd1Au2/C were noted to exhibit advantages of both single components with facile hydroxyl and carbonyl group oxidation resulting in greatly improved HMF conversion and selectivity towards FDCA. 3.4 The effect of the AuyPd1−y alloy formation To clarify the effect of the AuyPd1−y alloy formation on chemical oxidation of hydroxyl and carbonyl groups in HMF molecule, different steps of the consecutive HMF oxidation (Scheme 1) were additionally studied for the unsupported Au, Pd and 60Au40Pd particles using DFF, HMFCA, and FFCA as reagents. The corresponding kinetic dependencies are presented in Supplementary material, and Table 2 summarizes the apparent rate constants for different steps of HMF transformation. The Au and Pd monometallic samples are characterized by the kHMF rate constants of the HMF oxidation into DFF and HMFCA of 25 and 42 μmol l−1 s−1, respectively. For both Au and Pd samples, k2 and k3 rate constants of steps 2 and 3, respectively, are rather low (∼0.01 μmol l−1 s−1), while the k5 rate constant of step 5 is extremely high (700 and 1080 μmol l−1 s−1 for Au and Pd, respectively). This is consistent with negligible presence of DFF in the products due to its rapid transformation into FFCA. Considering the rather slow subsequent oxidation of both FFCA and HMFCA, the observed FFCA formation seems to be primarily through the DFF formation (steps 4 and 5 in Scheme 1), but not through the HMFCA oxidation (steps 1 and 2 in Scheme 1). In this regard, the HMFCA/FFCA molar ratio in the products at low HMF conversion should characterize the k1/k4 ratio. Such estimation shows that the rate constant of the hydroxyl group oxidation (step 4) is 2.7–3 times lower than the one of carbonyl group oxidation (step 1) in HMF molecule on the monometallic catalysts. For the 60Au40Pd sample, the kHMF rate constant is 4–6.7 times higher, and k2 and k3 rate constants are three orders of magnitude higher than the corresponding constants for the Au and Pd samples. The k5 rate constant for the 60Au40Pd sample is only 1.2–1.9 times higher than that for the monometallic samples but remains the highest one compared to rate constant of other steps causing the negligible DFF yield. However, the noticeable increase in the rate constants of other steps leads to high FFCA and FDCA yields. The estimation of the k1/k4 ratio from the HMFCA/FFCA molar ratio in the products at low HMF conversion shows that for the 60Au40Pd sample, the rate constant of step 4 is 2.7 times higher than the one of step 1. This indicates high catalytic activity of the 60Au40Pd sample towards oxidation of the hydroxyl group in HMF molecule to form DFF. The subsequent rapid oxidation of DFF followed by the relatively slow oxidation of the formed FFCA results in an accumulation of the latter as the main intermediate product. It is also noteworthy that according to the results of kinetic studies for intermediates, the FFCA oxidation on unsupported 100-xAuxPd metal samples is the slowest step of the consecutive HMF oxidation to FDCA, while the overall rate of the FDCA formation during the oxidation of HMF (∼0.24 μmol l−1 s−1) or HMFCA (∼0.13 μmol l−1 s−1) is higher than during the oxidation of DFF (∼0.05 μmol l−1 s−1) or FFCA (∼0.04 μmol l−1 s−1). This indicates more complex mechanism of FDCA formation on unsupported 100-xAu4xPd particles than straight consecutive oxidation via intermediate FFCA formation, with both induced reaction and one-step HMFCA oxidation pathways being possible. Similar accumulation of FFCA as the main product without its further conversion to FDCA was observed during the HMF and DFF oxidation on aryl-alcohol oxidase (AAO) [56]. The HMF oxidation on AAO proceeded via a consecutive selective oxidation pathway through DFF. The FFCA accumulation was shown to be due to the formation of H2O2 during the oxidation, while the addition of catalase removed H2O2 formed and led to complete HMF oxidation to FDCA. This phenomenon on 100-xAuxPd NPs requires further understanding and will be discussed elsewhere after detailed study. In general, the results obtained point out a synergistic effect for unsupported bimetallic 100-xAuxPd NPs as compared with monometallic Pd and Au NPs, with the AuyPd1−y alloy formation resulting in an increase of the catalytic activity towards hydroxyl group oxidation in HMF and HMFCA molecules. Such an improvement in the catalytic performance of the Pd1−yAuy alloys can be attributed to both ensemble and electronic effects providing the effective oxidation of both carbonyl and hydroxyl groups. Thus, for polycrystalline PdAu alloy samples, electron redistribution due to the hybridization in the alloy was shown to lead to a small net charge transfer from the Pd site to Au [57]. On the other hand, for AgPd catalysts, the activation of the species involved in the catalytic HMF oxidation was revealed to be affected by their adsorption, which depended on the structure of the catalyst surface sites [58]. According to the DFT calculations carried out in the present work for unsupported bimetallic AuPd clusters, the energies obtained for the gas-phase HMF binding to the considered cluster models reveal that the weakest binding occurs over Au20 cluster (−57 kJ/mol), and Pd20 ensures the strongest HMF binding (−124 kJ/mol). While Janus-like Au10Pd10 and Au8Pd12 clusters show rather similar binding energies (−112 and −117 kJ/mol, respectively), still the latter model featuring “homogeneous” distribution of metal atoms ensures higher degree of HMF molecule activation (Table S5). The Pd-containing models contribute to activation of the furan ring and both carboxyl and hydroxymethyl moieties in the HMF molecule, while gold atoms are mostly involved in interactions with hydroxyl and carbonyl groups. The Au8Pd12 cluster with “homogeneous” distribution of Au and Pd atoms was used in the calculations with the PCM model. The results obtained show that the energies of HMF binding with Au20 and Pd20 clusters are − 12 and − 105 kJ/mol, respectively, while the one for the Au8Pd12 cluster again occupies the intermediate position (−98 kJ/mol). In the latter case, the conformational change of the HMF molecule occurs at the interface between Au and Pd, where Pd atoms coordinate furan ring (Fig. S1C), and terminal Au atom coordinates hydroxyl part of the hydroxymethyl moiety. Thereby, the results obtained in the present work are consistent with the data obtained for similar systems [58] indicating that adsorption of the reactive species plays a critical role in the HMF oxidation. This issuer will be considered in detail and presented elsewhere. 4 Conclusions Monometallic Pd, Au, and bimetallic xAu1-xPd dispersions were successfully synthesized by PLA of individual Pd and Au targets in distilled water followed by laser fusion of Au and Pt NPs in mixed colloid, with the obtained colloidal metal and alloyed NPs remaining stable in pure water without the presence of any additional surfactant or organic ligand molecules. The formation of bimetallic AuyPd1−y alloyed NPs was confirmed by the UV–vis spectroscopy, XRD, SAED, and electrophoretic light scattering data. Unsupported single metal NPs (both Au and Pd) did not possess sufficient activity towards HMF oxidation to FDCA. The reaction proceeded mainly at the first stage via both carbonyl group oxidation to form HMFCA, with subsequent oxidation to FFCA and FDCA being complicated. The synergistic effect comprising the formation of Au-Pd interface in the alloy NPs, where the metals activated different moieties of the HMF molecule, was observed for unsupported bimetallic 100-xAuxPd NPs, with the AuyPd1−y alloy formation resulting in an increase of the catalytic activity towards hydroxyl group oxidation and providing higher activity and selectivity towards FFCA and FDCA. The catalytic performance of colloidal xAu1-xPd catalysts was strongly dependent on the Pd:Au ratio. The best catalytic performance was observed for 60Au40Pd sample showing 40 mol% FDCA yield at complete HMF conversion in 22 h of the reaction under condition used. coredata.dc:description: Bimetallic nanoparticles are of high interest for electronics, photonics, biomedicine, and heterogeneous catalysis. To reveal the effects of structure and composition of bimetallic nanoparticles on catalytic properties, unsupported particles with clean surfaces and well-defined characteristics should be considered. Herein, colloidal Au, Pd, and Au-Pd catalysts prepared by pulsed laser ablation in liquid are studied in 5-hydroxymethylfurfural (HMF) oxidation. The catalysts are characterized by ELS, UV–vis spectroscopy, XRD, TEM, and SAED methods. The results show the formation of Au1−yPdy alloy particles that remain stable in pure water without the presence of any surfactant and feature higher performance towards formylfuran carboxylic and furandicarboxylic acids as compared with monometallic samples. The results indicate the combined benefits of Pd1−yAuy alloys in aerobic catalytic HMF oxidation due to a synergistic effect comprising the formation of Au-Pd interface in alloy nanoparticles, where the metals activate different moieties of HMF molecule.
coredata.dc:title: Hydroxymethylfurfural oxidation over unsupported Pd-Au alloy catalysts prepared by pulsed laser ablation: Synergistic and compositional effects
